body:
There are googlers and non-googlers supporting this, there are googlers and non-googlers against this proposal. Let's leave googleness out of this, please.

The benefit is clear: you can move types (and functions, variables) to another package, without breaking compatibility. It doesn't help with adding breaking changes, yes, that's not what the proposal is about. That's a different problem.

You don't have to wait for people to migrate their code because you aren't making breaking changes. Again, you're discussing a different problem.

It adds very little complexity to the language. It's never been a disliked feature in other languages that I'm aware of.

I've asked if people can provide examples of aliasing being misused in other languages, that would be more constructive than just speculating that this will happen to Go.

The fact that the context package seems like a bad example to you should point you in the right direction: this proposal helps with it, SemVer doesn't. This proposal is about solving stuff like context, not for what SemVer is useful for.

Please provide an example with a couple of types of where SemVer would help and in which this proposal would too (so that it's a sort of counter-proposal).
